title-group.article-title: Dominantly Inherited Nonprogressive Cerebellar Hypoplasia Identified In Utero
title-group.subtitle: A Note of Doubt

contrib.aff: Division of Pediatric Radiology, The Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA
Department of Pediatric Neurology, University Children’s Hospital, Zurich, Switzerland

body.p: We read with great interest the article by Zerem et al 1 calling attention to the first description of prenatal diagnosis of autosomal dominant nonprogressive cerebellar ataxia, based on a fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at 25 weeks of gestation demonstrating a small cerebellum. The mother's MRI (2 illustrations are provided) shows indeed “extreme cerebellar hypoplasia”.
We have doubts about this interpretation:

list-item.p: The provided single axial fetal MRI section shows a small cerebellum with markedly reduced transverse diameter and the vermis is not identifiable. A reduced transverse diameter is not a specific finding. We have seen it in cerebellar hypoplasia of unknown etiology, pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 2, and rhombencephalosynapsis. 2,3 Rhombencephalosynapsis is characterized by absence of the cerebellar vermis and fusion of the cerebellar hemispheres and deep nuclei as well as the superior cerebellar peduncles. Developmental delay as reported in this infant is a common presentation of rhombencephalosynapsis. 4 A neuroimaging-based prenatal (postnatally confirmed) diagnosis of rhombencephalosynapsis is possible and has been reported as early as 21 weeks of gestation. As, unfortunately, no postnatal MRI is reported, this malformation is not excluded.

The MRI of the mother demonstrates a severe form of cerebellar hypoplasia. This finding is not specific and not diagnostic for any of the numerous genetic or acquired causes of cerebellar hypoplasia. 5

The authors appropriately draw attention to few pedigrees with autosomal dominant nonprogressive cerebellar ataxias. However, it is remarkable that imaging in these pedigrees describes or illustrates normal neuroimaging, mild cerebellar hypoplasia, or some degree of isolated vermis hypoplasia. 6
–9

body.p: Therefore, we find the arguments for a dominant nonprogressive cerebellar hypoplasia in the presented article not convincing.
